intro: Brassica rapa subf. oblonga, commonly known as the Chinese kale or Chinese broccoli, is a leafy vegetable characterized by its thick, edible stalks and crinkled, dark green leaves. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other cruciferous vegetables like broccoli and cauliflower. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces small, yellow flowers in the spring. It is native to East Asia and is cultivated for its nutrient-rich leaves and stems, which are used in various Asian cuisines. The plant prefers cool climates and well-drained soil, making it a popular crop in temperate regions.
